Content: Read paragraphs 2 and 3. Why did Joseph believe that human flight was possible?

A.Choice: He had observed elements in nature moving upward.

B.Choice: He had learned about human flight during his studies.

C.Choice: He had a dream in which he imagined seeing the world from high above.

D.Choice: He had heard that scientists were also wondering whether human flight could happen.

Content: Which quote from the passage is 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supported by the image and caption found at the end of the passage?

A.Choice: “On 27 August 1783, thousands of people assembled in Paris to witness the flight of Charles's Le Globe.” (paragraph 16)

B.Choice: “... Étienne demonstrated his new, handsewn aerostat to members of the Academy of Sciences.” (paragraph 19)

C.Choice: “Though the balloon rose up into the air, a sudden rain sent it crashing to the ground, destroying it.” (paragraph 19)

D.Choice: “Once in the air, another gust tilted it and sent a plume of smoke streaming out its side.” (paragraph 21)

Content: 𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
Based on the passage, which statement 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 describes Joseph?

A.Choice: He tries hard to win the approval of his family members.

B.Choice: He feels jealous of his brother's academic accomplishments.

C.Choice: He gets distracted and does not put much effort into his work.

D.Choice: He does not always agree with the plans made for him by others.

Content: Which quotation from the passage 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “'Surely, a human could lift off the ground and fly, too,' he told his brother Étienne.” (paragraph 3)

B.Choice: “Joseph grew so frustrated with his formal studies and his father's rigid ways that he left school.” (paragraph 5)

C.Choice: “Meanwhile, Étienne excelled in school, much to his father's delight.” (paragraph 6)

D.Choice: “Although he devised new kinds of paper and manufacturing techniques, most of the family was dismissive of his attempts at papermaking.” (paragraph 7)

Content: In paragraph 7, what does the word 𝗘𝗡𝗗𝗘𝗔𝗩𝗢𝗥 mean?

A.Choice: demand

B.Choice: location

C.Choice: attempt

D.Choice: business

Content: 𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
By describing Étienne as “worldly” in paragraph 15, what does the author suggest about him?

A.Choice: He has business knowledge and experience.

B.Choice: His ideas are creative and full of imagination.

C.Choice: He has met with the French royalty before.

D.Choice: His invention will inspire imitations by others.

Content: Which quotation from the passage 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “One day, he found himself considering the possibility of flight.” (paragraph 2)

B.Choice: “When he grew up, he became an architect, then, when his father retired, manager of the family business.” (paragraph 6)

C.Choice: “... they learned that their demonstration had prompted a prominent Parisian scientist, Jacques Charles, to begin work on a similar machine.” (paragraph 15)

D.Choice: “The great demonstration before the king and queen was scheduled in less than a week!” (paragraph 19)

Content: 𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
Which statement is a central idea of the passage?

A.Choice: Great achievements often require extra efforts.

B.Choice: It is important to respect nature and its limitations.

C.Choice: A successful life requires a formal education.

D.Choice: New ideas quickly gain approval from others.

Content: Which quotation from the passage 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “Greek, Latin, and theology were the subjects taught in his school, but it was science and mathematics that interested Joseph Montgolfier.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “Though many had tried, no human had ever flown before. Most people thought it impossible.” (paragraph 2)

C.Choice: “Meanwhile, Joseph's dream of flight remained just a dream.” (paragraph 7)

D.Choice: “The brothers quickly set to work experimenting. For months they tested many different bags...” (paragraph 12)

Content: In paragraph 6, what does the word 𝗙𝗟𝗨𝗥𝗥𝗜𝗘𝗗 mean?

A.Choice: upset

B.Choice: wise

C.Choice: rushed

D.Choice: helpful

Content: In paragraph 8, what does the word 𝗞𝗘𝗘𝗣𝗦𝗔𝗞𝗘 mean?

A.Choice: payment

B.Choice: souvenir

C.Choice: distraction

D.Choice: project

Content: 𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
Read paragraphs 10 through 12. What is suggested about the wolf?

A.Choice: He is lying to the goose.

B.Choice: He is happy to have a loyal friend.

C.Choice: He is concerned that the goose is being harmed.

D.Choice: He often praises the goose because he admires her so much.

Content: Which phrase taken from the passage 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the answer to part A?

A.Choice: “'Well begun is half done,' thought the wolf ...” (paragraph 10)

B.Choice: “... she made no objection to his walking along the road with her every morning.” (paragraph 10)

C.Choice: “'Dear me, something is pinching me!' the goose would say...” (paragraph 11)

D.Choice: “'It is the sun beating down,' the wolf would reply...” (paragraph 12)

Content: 𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
What is a theme of the passage?

A.Choice: Treat others as you would want to be treated.

B.Choice: Never stop seeking to learn new things.

C.Choice: Be happy with who you are and what you can do.

D.Choice: Honesty is the best way to make true friends.

Content: Which sentence taken from the passage 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the answer to part A?

A.Choice: “'Oh!' cried the wolf, 'I could not think it was worthless, for I so admire your beautiful wings.'” (paragraph 8)

B.Choice: “'... now they shall see a sight that will open their eyes!'” (paragraph 27)

C.Choice: “'It is true that you have harmed no one but yourself...'” (paragraph 33)

D.Choice: “'Had I heeded the grey goose and been satisfied to be a good wolf, I should be safe in my house to- day!'” (paragraph 35)

Content: 𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
Which statement 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 describes how the goose reacts to the wolf when she sees his wings?

A.Choice: She argues with him because he took her feathers.

B.Choice: She agrees that the feathers look beautiful on him.

C.Choice: She boasts that she is a better goose than he will ever be.

D.Choice: She pleads with him because she is worried about his safety.

Content: Which quotation from the passage 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “Now he must show the goose what a handsome bird he made...” (paragraph 16)

B.Choice: “When the grey goose saw him she was indeed surprised.” (paragraph 17)

C.Choice: “'Do not, I beg of you, try to fly!' she cried.” (paragraph 18)

D.Choice: “'I am indeed thankful that I am a goose, and shall be the best goose I know how to be!'” (paragraph 19)

Content: The descriptive language in paragraph 29 𝗠𝗔𝗜𝗡𝗟𝗬 contributes to the development of the plot by showing that the wolf

A.Choice: injures the goose to make his new wings.

B.Choice: damages the forest with his new wings.

C.Choice: fails in his attempt to fly with his new wings.

D.Choice: entertains his friends with his new wings.

Content: What is the meaning of the word 𝗛𝗔𝗨𝗚𝗛𝗧𝗬 as it is used in paragraph 12 of the passage “The Pedlar of Swaffham”?

A.Choice: in a familiar way

B.Choice: in a superior way

C.Choice: in a curious way

D.Choice: in a polite way

Content: 𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
How do paragraphs 1 through 3 in “The Pedlar of Swaffham” contribute to the development of the plot of the passage?

A.Choice: by revealing how the pedlar is viewed by others

B.Choice: by suggesting that the pedlar is having a hard time

C.Choice: by suggesting that the pedlar's home will be important later on

D.Choice: by revealing why the pedlar feels so tired when coming home

Content: Which detail from the passage 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “The pedlar had a cottage...” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “... he traveled from village to village...” (paragraph 1)

C.Choice: “... townsfolk enjoyed the friendly pedlar's company...” (paragraph 3)

D.Choice: “... he rarely sold anything.” (paragraph 3)

Content: Which 𝗧𝗪𝗢 details should be included in a summary of the passage “The Pedlar of Swaffham”?

A.Choice: A shopkeeper in London tells the pedlar about his dream about digging up gold in Swaffham.

B.Choice: A dream had little effect on the pedlar, but then he had the same dream two more times.

C.Choice: The pedlar in Swaffham dreams about hearing good news on London Bridge.

D.Choice: People in London who are crossing the bridge yell at the pedlar.

E.Choice: The pedlar has trouble selling anything to people crossing London Bridge.

Content: What is the meaning of the word bankrupt as it is used in paragraph 8 of “The Wheat on the Chessboard”?

A.Choice: completely out of a supply

B.Choice: unable to find a solution

C.Choice: unable to count a quantity

D.Choice: assigned to another role

Content: 𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
How does the author develop the point of view of the treasurer and other courtiers in paragraphs 4 through 7 of the passage “The Wheat on the Chessboard”?

A.Choice: by describing the courtiers' reaction to Sessa's silence at the palace

B.Choice: by highlighting the courtiers' rising awareness of their own ignorance

C.Choice: by suggesting why the courtiers must wait for the king's order for the payment

D.Choice: by explaining why the courtiers are left out of important decisions the king makes

Content: Which 𝗧𝗪𝗢 details from the passage 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 support the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “'If that's all he wants,' he told his treasurer, 'give it to him!'” (paragraph 4)

B.Choice: “... the treasurer presented Sessa with a single grain of wheat...” (paragraph 5)

C.Choice: “The great lords roared with laughter. But Sessa kept his thoughts to himself.” (paragraph 5)

D.Choice: “The courtiers stopped laughing and started whispering.” (paragraph 6)

E.Choice: “... the treasurer began to look worried. Quaking in his boots, he went to see the king.” (paragraph 7)

Content: 𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
How does the king's attitude change during the passage “The Wheat on the Chessboard”?

A.Choice: At first the king feels that Sessa should be made rich, but then he understands that Sessa is a simple man.

B.Choice: At first the king believes his power comes from his riches, but then he understands the power in using wisdom to make decisions.

C.Choice: At first the king thinks of chess as just a game, but then he understands that there are real consequences involved in chess.

D.Choice: At first the king regards his kingdom as being rich in grain, but then he understands the lack of wheat production.

Content: Which 𝗧𝗪𝗢 details from the passage 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 support the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “The king ... told Sessa to name anything he liked as his reward, boasting that the wealth of his kingdom was limitless.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “'Very well!' said the king, a little irritated, thinking that Sessa was mocking his wealth.” (paragraph 4)

C.Choice: “The king was amazed by the treasurer's words, but he checked and double- checked the arithmetic, and there was no doubt.” (paragraph 9)

D.Choice: “There was nothing for the king to do but call Sessa before him, confess the foolishness of his rash promise...” (paragraph 10)

E.Choice: “... the king and Sessa remained the best of friends and enjoyed many games of chess together.” (paragraph 12)

Content: 𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
Which statement 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 states a theme that is developed in 𝗕𝗢𝗧𝗛 passages?

A.Choice: People should consider advice they receive.

B.Choice: A simple invention can change the world.

C.Choice: Many rewards involve taking worthwhile risks.

D.Choice: Good leadership comes from years of experience.

Content: Which statement about 𝗕𝗢𝗧𝗛 passages 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: The pedlar learns to pay close attention to people, and the king sees the value in chess.

B.Choice: The pedlar finds wealth through adventure, and the king appreciates Sessa for challenging him.

C.Choice: The pedlar is treated badly by others, and the king feels insulted by a request Sessa makes.

D.Choice: The pedlar works hard to sell useful things, and the king keeps wheat in storage.

Content: How do the narrators of 𝗕𝗢𝗧𝗛 “The Pedlar of Swaffham” and “The Wheat on the Chessboard” reveal that the main character shows determination?

A.Choice: by sharing the main character's thoughts as he considers ways to solve a problem

B.Choice: by describing the main character's attempts to become more respected by others

C.Choice: by emphasizing the reason the main character begins to question his situation

D.Choice: by showing that the main character follows a plan despite an unknown outcome

Content: The main characters in “The Pedlar of Swaffham” and “The Wheat on the Chessboard” share similar character traits. Write a response analyzing how their shared traits contribute to the development of the theme of the two stories. Use evidence from 𝗕𝗢𝗧𝗛 passages to support your ideas.
In paragraph 5 of “Dissect a Flower,” the 𝗣𝗜𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗟 is the part of the plant that

A.Choice: grows the pollen.

B.Choice: attracts bees and insects.

C.Choice: holds the ovary.

D.Choice: produces a sweet smell.

Content: What are 𝗧𝗪𝗢 purposes for including the picture of the flower in “Dissect a Flower”?

A.Choice: to label the individual parts of a flower

B.Choice: to support the idea that flowers are attractive

C.Choice: to reveal how a flower looks under a magnifying glass

D.Choice: to show how a flower looks when whole and when separated

E.Choice: to demonstrate how to cut a flower using scissors

Content: 𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
Which central idea about flowers is 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supported in the passage “Dissect a Flower”?

A.Choice: The purpose of flowers is to make plants look appealing.

B.Choice: Flowers exist to attract pollinators for reproduction.

C.Choice: The petals are the most noticeable part of a flower.

D.Choice: Most flowering plants are brightly colored.

Content: Which quotation from the passage 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “... and flowers sprout, displaying beautiful colors and sometimes spreading a delightful scent.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “If you look closely at a flower, you might see that it is made of many different parts...” (paragraph 2)

C.Choice: “Some flowering plants have a stem, which is a long stalk that carries water and nutrients and supports the flower.” (paragraph 3)

D.Choice: “... a flower is much more than just beautiful to look at: it is essential for a plant to create more plants.” (paragraph 6)

Content: 𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
What is the meaning of 𝗗𝗜𝗚𝗘𝗦𝗧 as it is used in paragraph 4 of “Venus Flytrap”?

A.Choice: attract

B.Choice: identify

C.Choice: capture

D.Choice: consume

Content: Which quotation from paragraph 4 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 supports the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “The Venus flytrap gets some of its nutrients from the soil...”

B.Choice: “... to supplement its diet, the plant eats insects and arachnids.”

C.Choice: “Ants, beetles, grasshoppers, flying insects, and spiders are all victims of the flytrap.”

D.Choice: “... it may go months between meals.”

Content: According to “Venus Flytrap,” what effect do forest fires have on the survival of Venus flytraps?

A.Choice: They create an area below the surface where Venus flytraps can grow.

B.Choice: They block out the sunlight that Venus flytraps need.

C.Choice: They reduce the amount of moisture available to Venus flytraps.

D.Choice: They cause an increase in the insects that Venus flytraps prey upon.

Content: In “Venus Flytrap,” the author's concluding opinion about the plant is that it

A.Choice: remains an interesting addition to forests.

B.Choice: absorbs energy from the sun more quickly than other plants.

C.Choice: uses an efficient and creative method to capture prey.

D.Choice: might disappear due to environmental changes.

Content: 𝗧𝗛𝗜𝗦 𝗤𝗨𝗘𝗦𝗧𝗜𝗢𝗡 𝗛𝗔𝗦 𝗧𝗪𝗢 𝗣𝗔𝗥𝗧𝗦.
What is a central idea in “Venus Flytrap”?

A.Choice: Venus flytraps are aggressive hunters.

B.Choice: Venus flytraps require a great deal of care.

C.Choice: Venus flytraps need specific conditions to thrive.

D.Choice: Venus flytraps are common household plants.

Content: Which 𝗧𝗪𝗢 details from the passage 𝗕𝗘𝗦𝗧 support the answer to Part A?

A.Choice: “The 'trap' is made of two hinged lobes at the end of each leaf.” (paragraph 1)

B.Choice: “To prevent the plant from wasting energy if prey isn't actually there ...” (paragraph 1)

C.Choice: “It is popular as a potted plant in many parts of the world...” (paragraph 2)

D.Choice: “Venus flytraps need an open understory (the part of the forest below the canopy) to live.” (paragraph 3)

E.Choice: “This results in less suitable habitat for the sun- loving Venus flytrap.” (paragraph 3)

Content: According to “Dissect a Flower” and “Venus Flytrap,” what are 𝗧𝗪𝗢 ways in which Venus flytraps are 𝗦𝗜𝗠𝗜𝗟𝗔𝗥 to other plants?

A.Choice: They use photosynthesis to receive energy from the sun.

B.Choice: They reproduce by growing flowers that are pollinated.

C.Choice: They feed on insects by catching them in traps.

D.Choice: They grow large flowers that produce a sweet odor.

E.Choice: They are made up of parts that are easy to examine.

Content: You have read two passages about plants. “Dissect a Flower” provides an experiment a reader can perform to learn about plants, while “Venus Flytrap” provides facts and descriptions to help the reader learn. Which type of passage provides a better opportunity for learning?
Write a response arguing whether a reader learns more from thinking through an experiment or from thinking through facts and descriptions. Use information from 𝗕𝗢𝗧𝗛 passages in your argument.
